channel.title: NYT > Health
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Disappearing Doctor: How Mega-Mergers Are Changing the Business of Medical Care
item.media:description: Dr. Navya Mysore was frustrated while working for a large New York health system, so she moved to One Medical, a venture-backed practice, where she gets to spend more time with her patients.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: Big corporations — giant retailers and health insurance companies — are teaming up to become your doctor.
item.dc:creator: REED ABELSON and JULIE CRESWELL

item.title: Ask Well: How Can Oats, Which Don’t Contain Gluten, Be Labeled ‘Gluten Free’?
item.description: Oats, water, even sneakers may be advertised as “gluten-free.”
item.dc:creator: SOPHIE EGAN

item.title: A Better Body in a Pill? Experts Urge Caution on SARMs
item.description: Bodybuilders are turning to a popular new pill to get bigger and stronger, but the chemicals are still undergoing testing and could cause serious harm.
item.dc:creator: ANAHAD O’CONNOR

item.title: Phys Ed: Why Exercise Alone May Not Be the Key to Weight Loss
item.description: Mice given free access to running wheels moved less after exercising, which may have implications for diets and weight loss in people.
item.dc:creator: GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

item.title: Many People Taking Antidepressants Discover They Cannot Quit
item.media:description: Victoria Toline needed nine months to taper off Zoloft. “I had to drop out of school,” she said. “My life’s been on hold.”
item.description: Long-term use of the medications is surging in the United States, according to an analysis by The Times. One reason: withdrawal symptoms that make it difficult to stop.
item.dc:creator: BENEDICT CAREY and ROBERT GEBELOFF

item.title: Air Pollution May Pose Serious Risks to Young Children
item.description: Air pollution increases the number of lower respiratory infections, a leading cause of illness and death in children under 2.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Personal Health: Why You Should Get the New Shingles Vaccine
item.description: People 50 and older should get the new shingles vaccine whether or not they remember having had chickenpox as a child, experts say.
item.dc:creator: JANE E. BRODY

item.title: Trilobites: He Ate the World’s Hottest Pepper, Then Landed in the Hospital With ‘Thunderclap’ Headaches
item.media:description: A Carolina Reaper, the hottest pepper in the world. It has recently been measured at more than two million Scoville heat units; a really hot habanero might come in at 500,000 units.
item.description: After eating the Carolina Reaper during a contest, an unidentified patient suffered headaches so severe he was hospitalized. The symptoms resembled those of a stroke.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN

item.title: Scientist Behind Dolly the Sheep, a Key to Parkinson’s Research, Has the Disease Himself
item.media:description: An undated photograph of Dr. Ian Wilmut with Dolly the sheep at the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh.
item.description: Dr. Ian Wilmut said he received the diagnosis four months ago and would participate in a major research program to test new types of treatments.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Matter: All by Itself, the Humble Sweet Potato Colonized the World
item.media:description: The distribution of the sweet potato plant has baffled scientists. How could the plant arise from a wild ancestor in the Americas and wind up on islands across the Pacific?
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: Many botanists argued that humans must have carried the valuable staple to the Pacific from South America, a hidden chapter in human history. Not so, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Morning People May Live Longer Than Night Owls
item.description: Compared with “definite morning” types, “definite evening” types had a 10 percent increased risk of dying over a six-and-a-half-year study period.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Ruth Nussenzweig, Who Pursued Malaria Vaccine, Dies at 89
item.media:description: Ruth Nussenzweig in an undated family photo. Escaping oppression in Europe and then Brazil “strengthened my resources and hardened my will to be a scientist,” she said.
item.description: Dr. Nussenzweig’s research into one of the world’s most deadly diseases laid the groundwork for an approach once thought beyond reach.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GENZLINGER
item.category: New York University Langone Medical Center

item.title: Republicans Couldn’t Knock Down Obamacare. So They’re Finding Ways Around It.
item.media:description: Seema Verma, the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, during a visit to Nashville last month. On Monday, she unveiled a series of policies that were aimed at working around Obamacare's requirements.
item.description: Alongside one health care market, a parallel one, with fewer rules.
item.dc:creator: MARGOT SANGER-KATZ
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Chinese Sperm Bank Seeks Donors. Only Good Communists Need Apply.
item.media:description: A lab technician at the fertility clinic of Peking University Third Hospital in Beijing in 2005.
item.description: A Beijing hospital advertised for donors with “good ideological thoughts” who “support the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party.”
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Adolescence: Why Teenagers Become ‘Allergic’ to Their Parents
item.description: It’s no small task for teenagers to detach from those who have superintended nearly every aspect of their lives so far.
item.dc:creator: LISA DAMOUR

item.title: Traumatic Brain Injuries Are Tied to Dementia
item.description: Even a single mild concussion was tied to an increased risk of dementia.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Trilobites: Why Scientists Are Battling Over Pleasure
item.media:description: Is the pleasure of enjoying a Leonardo da Vinci painting really any different than the pleasure we get from eating chocolate?
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.description: The question of whether the benefit from viewing a da Vinci is different from enjoying a visit to Pornhub or McDonald’s is dividing psychologists and neuroscientists.
item.dc:creator: HEATHER MURPHY
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

item.title: F.D.A. Restricts Sales of Bayer’s Essure Contraceptive Implant
item.media:description: Dr. Scott Gottlieb, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, did not accede to demands to remove Essure, the troubled contraceptive implant, from the market. Instead, he ordered its manufacturer, Bayer, to limit sales.
item.description: The agency said the device could only be sold by doctors who agree to warn women of the serious risks associated with it.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA KAPLAN

item.title: They Were Jailed for Miscarriages. Now, Campaign Aims to End Abortion Ban.
item.media:description: Women at risk of premature birth resting at El Hospital de La Mujer in San Salvador.
item.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
item.description: Women’s rights groups in El Salvador are urging lawmakers to allow abortions when a woman’s life is at risk and for minors who are raped.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Doctors Urge Elite Academy to Expel a Member Over Charges of Plagiarism
item.media:description: The National Academy of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine building in Washington.
item.media:credit: Carol M. Highsmith/Buyenlarge, via Getty Images
item.description: National Academy of Medicine was asked to tighten ethics rules following the strange case of a member accused of plagiarism and false claims of top scientific honors.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA KAPLAN
item.category: Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences

item.title: It’s the Latest in Conservation Tech. And It Wants to Suck Your Blood.
item.media:description: A leech, Haemadipsa zeylanica, in Thailand. Scientists have found they can survey the biodiversity of a forest with DNA analysis of leeches’ last blood meals.
item.description: In the digestive tracts of leeches, scientists find evidence of elusive forest species.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER

item.title: The Checkup: Life-Threatening Allergic Reactions Rising in Children
item.media:credit: Andrew Mangum for The New York Times
item.description: The rate of emergency room visits for anaphylaxis more than doubled, to 3.5 visits per 10,000 children in 2016 from 1.4 in 2010.
item.dc:creator: PERRI KLASS, M.D.

item.title: The New Health Care: Better Car Seats Are Just the Start: Road Safety Lessons From Sweden
item.media:description: Crash-test dummies used to compare different styles of child safety seats. The top row are U.S.-style, while the lower row are the Swedish version.
item.media:credit: Association for the Advancement of Automotive Medicine
item.description: The United States could do a lot more to make car travel safer for children and easier on parents.
item.dc:creator: AARON E. CARROLL

item.title: Michigan Will No Longer Provide Free Bottled Water to Flint
item.media:description: Deon Sisco loading cases of bottled water into vehicles in Flint, Mich., on Friday. The governor said the state would discontinue providing the free bottles.
item.media:credit: Jake May/The Flint Journal-MLive.com, via Associated Press
item.description: The state said the city’s water supply now met federal standards for safe levels of lead, but city officials were concerned, noting that lead pipes are still in service.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Surgery Lit by Cellphone: Togo Doctors Strike Over Deplorable Hospitals
item.media:description: Togolese women protested in the streets of the capital, Lomé, during a January rally against President Faure Gnassingbé, whose family has ruled the country for five decades.
item.description: To protest overcrowded and undersupplied hospitals, health care workers in the West African nation are staging walkouts, adding their voices to a growing swell of political opposition.
item.dc:creator: TIM MCDONNELL

item.title: Why Trump’s Tariffs Could Raise the Cost of a Hip Replacement
item.media:description: Defibrillators, replacement joints, pacemakers, insulin and lidocaine: All are made in China, and all are among the items targeted by the Trump administration’s tariffs.
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: MedStockPhotos, Scott Camazine, MedStockPhontos, Mohammed Anwarul Kabir Choudhury and Dario Lo Presti, via Alamy.
item.description: A growing percentage of medical devices and drugs used in American operating rooms are made in China, and many of them are on the White House’s list.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA KAPLAN and KATIE THOMAS

item.title: Opinion: The Germs That Love Diet Soda
item.description: Human beings aren’t designed to eat processed foods like these.
item.dc:creator: MOISES VELASQUEZ-MANOFF

item.title: Q&A: In Your Bathroom, the Scum of the Earth
item.description: Why does bar soap clog the bathroom drain?
item.dc:creator: C. CLAIBORNE RAY

item.title: Global Health: TB Treatment May Leave Some Patients Contagious
item.media:description: An H.I.V.-positive woman with tuberculosis symptoms at a hospital in Uganda. Researchers studying TB patients who were also infected with H.I.V. found that they may require higher doses of the standard medications.
item.description: Standard doses of two TB drugs were insufficient in African subjects also infected with H.I.V., a study finds. Experts say treatment guidelines should be revised.
item.dc:creator: EMILY BAUMGAERTNER

item.title: What Is Naloxone and How Does It Stop Opioid Overdoses?
item.media:description: A kit containing naloxone, the opioid overdose antidote that the surgeon general is advising more Americans to keep nearby.
item.description: Each day 115 Americans die of an opioid overdose. In the first surgeon general advisory in 13 years, Americans were urged to carry a medication to save lives.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH DIAS and ANNIE CORREAL
